Significant figures rules and operations. Rounding off. Order of magnitude. Accuracy and precision. Random and systematic errors. Combination of errors. Vernier calipers and screw gauge least count. Dimensional analysis applications and limitations.

Motion in a Straight Line.notes: This chapter covers frame of reference, rest and motion, distance vs displacement, speed vs velocity. Uniform and non-uniform motion. Acceleration, retardation. Position-time, velocity-time, acceleration-time graphs. Area under v-t curve gives displacement. Slope of s-t curve gives velocity. Free fall under gravity (g = 9.8 m/s²). Equations of motion under gravity with sign convention. Relative motion concepts. Stopping distance, reaction time.

Motion in a Plane.notes: This chapter introduces scalars and vectors with their properties. Position and displacement vectors in 2D and 3D. Multiplication of vectors: dot and cross products with their physical significance. Projectile motion as combination of horizontal uniform motion and vertical accelerated motion. Equation of trajectory is parabolic. Angular projection, horizontal projection. Maximum range at 45°. Circular motion: angular displacement, angular velocity, angular acceleration. Relation between linear and angular variables. Centripetal force directed towards center. Banking of roads (basic concept).

Laws of Motion.notes: This chapter covers Newton's three laws of motion with their applications. Inertia and mass. Equilibrium of concurrent forces. Free body diagram technique. Impulse and impulsive forces. Conservation of linear momentum. Friction: static, kinetic and rolling friction, their properties and graphs. Factors affecting friction. Advantages and disadvantages of friction. Methods to reduce friction. Dynamics of uniform circular motion: centripetal force vs centrifugal force (pseudo force). Vehicle on banked road. Motion in a vertical circle (minimum velocity at lowest/highest point).

Work, Energy and Power.notes: This chapter deals with work as scalar product of force and displacement. Positive, negative and zero work conditions. Conservative vs non-conservative forces. Mechanical energy and its conservation. Potential energy curves and equilibrium (stable, unstable, neutral). Power: average and instantaneous. Collisions: elastic, inelastic and perfectly inelastic. Coefficient of restitution. Head-on and oblique collisions. Applications in daily life: pendulum, roller coaster, spring systems. Relation between force and potential energy: F = -dU/dr.

System of Particles and Rotational Motio.notes: This chapter extends mechanics to rotational motion. Center of mass for discrete and continuous systems. Motion of CM represents overall motion. Rigid body: translational + rotational motion. Moment of inertia depends on mass distribution and axis of rotation. Torque as rotational analogue of force. Angular momentum and its conservation (Kepler's law application). Rotational work and power. Equilibrium of rigid bodies. Rolling motion: combination of translation and rotation. Sliding vs rolling friction. Applications: flywheel, gyroscope, bicycles.

Gravitation.notes: This chapter covers universal law of gravitation and its vector form. Gravitational constant and its significance. Acceleration due to gravity and its variation with height, depth, latitude, and Earth's rotation. Gravitational field and intensity. Gravitational potential and potential energy for point mass and spherical shell/solid sphere. Escape velocity and its relation with temperature for gases. Satellites: polar, equatorial, geostationary, geosynchronous. Orbital energy: KE, PE and total energy. Parking orbits. Weightlessness concept. Inertial and gravitational mass. Black holes basic idea.

Mechanical Properties of Solids.notes: This chapter introduces elasticity and plasticity. Types of stress: tensile, compressive, hydraulic, shearing. Types of strain: longitudinal, volumetric, shearing. Hooke's law and its limit. Stress-strain diagram for ductile and brittle materials: proportional limit, elastic limit, yield point, ultimate strength, fracture point. Young's modulus for different materials. Applications: beams, columns, bridges. Factors affecting elasticity. Elastic hysteresis. Elastomers. Poisson's effect. Relationship between elastic constants (derivation included). Practical applications in daily life and engineering.

Mechanical Properties of Fluids.notes: This chapter covers fluids (liquids and gases). Thrust and pressure. Pascal's law and hydraulic machines (lift, brake). Atmospheric pressure and its measurement (barometer). Manometers. Buoyancy and floatation: apparent weight. Streamline and turbulent flow. Critical velocity. Viscosity coefficient and its variation with temperature. Poiseuille's equation for flow through tube. Surface tension: molecular theory, surface energy. Factors affecting surface tension. Angle of contact and its effects. Capillarity and its examples. Detergents and surface tension. Applications in biology and engineering.

Thermal Properties of Matter.notes: This chapter deals with heat and temperature. Thermometers and temperature scales. Thermal expansion in solids, liquids and gases. Anomalous expansion of water. Specific heat capacity of solids, liquids and gases (Cp and Cv). Calorimetry and principle of heat exchange. Change of state: fusion, vaporization, sublimation. Latent heat. Triple point. Heat transfer: conduction (thermal conductivity, thermal resistance), convection (natural and forced), radiation. Black body radiation. Stefan-Boltzmann law. Wien's law. Greenhouse effect. Newton's law of cooling and its verification. Thermal equilibrium.

formulas: First law: ΔU = Q + W (chemistry sign) or ΔU = Q - W (physics sign)

For diatomic gas: Cv = 5R/2, Cp = 7R/2, γ = 7/5
Isothermal process: PV = constant, W = nRT ln(V₂/V₁), ΔU = 0, Q = W
Adiabatic process: PV^γ = constant, TV^(γ-1) = constant, Q = 0, ΔU = -W
Isobaric process: P = constant, W = PΔV, Q = nCpΔT
Isochoric process: V = constant, W = 0, Q = nCvΔT
Heat engine efficiency: η = 1 - Q₂/Q₁ = 1 - T₂/T₁ (Carnot)
Refrigerator coefficient: β = Q₂/W = T₂/(T₁ - T₂)

Thermodynamics.notes: This chapter covers fundamental principles of heat and work. Thermodynamic systems (open, closed, isolated). Thermodynamic variables (P, V, T) and state functions. Thermal equilibrium and Zeroth law. First law: conservation of energy. Indicator diagrams and work calculation. Various thermodynamic processes and their characteristics. Specific heat capacities of gases. Meyer's relation. Reversible and irreversible processes. Second law: direction of heat flow. Heat engines and refrigerators. Carnot cycle: most efficient. Carnot theorem. Entropy and its physical meaning. Third law of thermodynamics (basic idea).

Kinetic Theory.notes: This chapter explains macroscopic properties from molecular behavior. Assumptions of kinetic theory. Derivation of gas laws from kinetic theory (Boyle's, Charles', Avogadro's). RMS speed and its temperature dependence. Different average speeds and their applications. Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution curve: most probable speed, average speed, RMS speed. Effect of temperature and mass on distribution. Degrees of freedom for monatomic, diatomic and polyatomic gases. Equipartition of energy. Specific heat capacities of gases and their temperature dependence. Mean free path and its factors. Real gases vs ideal gases. Van der Waals equation for real gases. Boyle temperature.

Oscillations.notes: This chapter covers periodic and oscillatory motion. SHM as projection of uniform circular motion. Characteristics: amplitude, period, frequency, phase, epoch. Energy variation with displacement. Graphical representation of displacement, velocity, acceleration. Angular SHM. Simple pendulum: approximation for small angles. Spring-mass system: horizontal and vertical. Compound pendulum. Combination of springs. Damped oscillations: underdamped, critically damped, overdamped. Forced oscillations and resonance. Sharpness of resonance. Quality factor. Applications: tuning forks, musical instruments, earthquakes, bridges. Lissajous figures.

Waves.notes: This chapter covers mechanical waves. Types: transverse and longitudinal. Progressive waves: displacement relation. Speed of wave in different media: string, solids, liquids, gases. Factors affecting wave speed. Laplace correction for sound in gases. Energy and power in waves. Intensity and loudness. Reflection of waves: phase change. Principle of superposition. Interference of waves: constructive and destructive. Standing waves in strings: harmonics and overtones. Modes of vibration. Sonometer experiment. Standing waves in pipes: open and closed. End correction. Beats and their applications. Doppler effect: source moving, observer moving, both moving. Applications: radar, sonar, medical imaging (ultrasound), red shift in astronomy.

Law of conservation of mass: Mass can neither be created nor destroyed
Law of definite proportions: A compound always contains same elements in fixed ratio
Law of multiple proportions: When two elements form multiple compounds, masses of one element combine with fixed mass of other in small whole number ratio
Gay-Lussac's law: Gases combine in simple whole number ratio by volume
Avogadro's law: Equal volumes of gases at same T&P contain equal number of molecules
definitions: Mole: Amount of substance containing same number of particles as atoms in 12 g of C-12
Avogadro's number: Number of particles in one mole = 6.022 × 10²³
Molar mass: Mass of one mole of substance in grams
Atomic mass: Mass of one atom relative to 1/12th mass of C-12 atom
Molecular mass: Sum of atomic masses of all atoms in molecule
Formula mass: Sum of atomic masses in formula unit (for ionic compounds)
Empirical formula: Simplest whole number ratio of atoms in compound
Molecular formula: Actual number of atoms in molecule
Molarity: Number of moles of solute per liter of solution
Molality: Number of moles of solute per kg of solvent
Mole fraction: Ratio of moles of one component to total moles
Limiting reagent: Reactant that limits amount of product formed
Stoichiometry: Quantitative relationship between reactants and products
Significant figures: Digits that carry meaningful information in measurement
Precision: Closeness of multiple measurements to each other
Accuracy: Closeness of measurement to true value

formulas: ν̄ = 1/λ = R(1/n₁² - 1/n₂²) (Wave number for H spectrum)
Eₙ = -13.6/n² eV (Energy of electron in H atom)

Number of photons = Power × time / Energy per photon
l = 0 to n-1 (Azimuthal quantum number values)
definitions: Cathode rays: Streams of electrons emitted from cathode in discharge tube
Anode rays: Positively charged rays moving towards cathode
Atomic number (Z): Number of protons in nucleus
Mass number (A): Number of protons + neutrons
Isotopes: Same atomic number, different mass number
Isobars: Same mass number, different atomic number
Isotones: Same number of neutrons
Isoelectronic: Same number of electrons
Electromagnetic radiation: Energy waves with electric and magnetic fields
Quantum: Smallest packet of energy
Photon: Particle of light with energy hν
Photoelectric effect: Emission of electrons when light falls on metal surface
Work function: Minimum energy to eject electron from metal surface
Atomic spectrum: Pattern of lines when light from atom is dispersed
Line spectrum: Discontinuous spectrum with specific wavelengths
Bohr's model: Planetary model with quantized orbits
Ground state: Lowest energy state of atom
Excited state: Higher energy state than ground state
Ionization energy: Energy required to remove electron from atom
de Broglie wavelength: Wavelength associated with moving particle
Heisenberg uncertainty principle: Cannot simultaneously know position and momentum exactly
Quantum number: Numbers describing electron's position and energy
Principal quantum number (n): Main energy level
Azimuthal quantum number (l): Subshell shape
Magnetic quantum number (m): Orbital orientation
Spin quantum number (s): Electron spin direction
Orbital: Region with high probability of finding electron
Aufbau principle: Electrons fill lowest energy orbitals first
Pauli exclusion principle: No two electrons have same set of quantum numbers
Hund's rule: Electrons occupy orbitals singly before pairing
Electronic configuration: Distribution of electrons in orbitals

formulas: Atomic radius = Distance between nucleus and outermost electron
Ionic radius = Distance between nucleus and outermost electron in ion
Covalent radius = Half of distance between nuclei of two bonded atoms
Van der Waals radius = Half of distance between non-bonded atoms
Ionization enthalpy (IE) = Energy required to remove electron from gaseous atom
Electron gain enthalpy (ΔegH) = Energy released when electron added to gaseous atom
Electronegativity (χ) = Tendency to attract shared electrons
Slater's rule for effective nuclear charge: Z* = Z - σ
Periods: Horizontal rows in periodic table
Groups: Vertical columns in periodic table
definitions: Periodic law: Properties of elements are periodic function of atomic numbers
Modern periodic table: Elements arranged by increasing atomic number
Period: Horizontal row with same number of shells
Group: Vertical column with same valence electrons
s-block: Groups 1-2, valence electrons in s orbital
p-block: Groups 13-18, valence electrons in p orbital
d-block: Groups 3-12, valence electrons in d orbital (transition elements)
f-block: Lanthanides and actinides (inner transition elements)
Atomic radius: Size of atom
Covalent radius: Half distance between bonded atoms
Van der Waals radius: Half distance between non-bonded atoms
Ionic radius: Size of ion
Ionization enthalpy: Energy to remove electron from gaseous atom
Electron gain enthalpy: Energy released when electron added to gaseous atom
Electronegativity: Tendency to attract shared electrons
Effective nuclear charge: Net positive charge experienced by electron
Shielding effect: Inner electrons shield outer electrons from nucleus
Periodicity: Repetition of properties after regular intervals
Metals: Elements that lose electrons, form positive ions
Non-metals: Elements that gain electrons, form negative ions
Metalloids: Elements with properties of both metals and non-metals
Noble gases: Group 18 elements, stable electronic configuration
Transition elements: d-block elements with partially filled d orbitals
Lanthanoids: f-block elements from Ce to Lu
Actinoids: f-block elements from Th to Lr

formulas: Octet rule: Atoms tend to achieve 8 electrons in valence shell
Bond length = Distance between bonded nuclei
Bond angle = Angle between two bonds
Bond enthalpy = Energy required to break one mole of bonds
Dipole moment (μ) = q × d (q = charge, d = distance)
Hybridization = Number of sigma bonds + Lone pairs
sp² hybridization: Trigonal planar, bond angle 120°
VSEPR theory: Shape determined by repulsion between electron pairs
Molecular orbital configuration: σ1s, σ*1s, σ2s, σ*2s, σ2pz, π2px = π2py, π*2px = π*2py, σ*2pz
Magnetic property: Paramagnetic if unpaired electrons, Diamagnetic if all paired
definitions: Chemical bond: Force holding atoms together
Ionic bond: Complete transfer of electrons, electrostatic force
Covalent bond: Sharing of electrons
Coordinate bond: Both electrons from one atom
Metallic bond: Electrostatic attraction between metal ions and delocalized electrons
Lewis structure: Representation showing valence electrons
Octet rule: Atoms achieve noble gas configuration
Formal charge: Charge on atom in Lewis structure
Resonance: Delocalization of electrons in multiple structures
Polar bond: Unequal sharing of electrons
Non-polar bond: Equal sharing of electrons
Dipole moment: Measure of bond polarity
Bond parameters: Bond length, bond angle, bond enthalpy
VSEPR theory: Valence Shell Electron Pair Repulsion theory
Hybridization: Mixing of atomic orbitals to form new hybrid orbitals
Molecular orbital theory: Combination of atomic orbitals to form molecular orbitals
Bonding molecular orbital: Lower energy, electron density between nuclei
Antibonding molecular orbital: Higher energy, electron density away from nuclei
Bond order: Number of bonds between atoms
Paramagnetic: Attracted to magnetic field (unpaired electrons)
Diamagnetic: Repelled by magnetic field (all paired)
Hydrogen bond: Attraction between H and electronegative atom (F, O, N)
Intermolecular forces: Forces between molecules
van der Waals forces: Weak attractive forces between molecules

formulas: ΔU = q + w (First law of thermodynamics)
w = -nRT ln(V₂/V₁) (Isothermal reversible work for ideal gas)
ΔH = ΔU + Δn_gRT (Relation between ΔH and ΔU)
ΔH_reaction = Σ Bond energies(reactants) - Σ Bond energies(products)
Hess's law: ΔH is independent of path
ΔS_total = ΔS_system + ΔS_surroundings > 0 for spontaneous process
ΔG° = -RT ln K (Relation with equilibrium constant)
Spontaneous if ΔG < 0, Non-spontaneous if ΔG > 0, Equilibrium if ΔG = 0
Third law: Entropy of perfect crystal at 0 K is zero
definitions: Thermodynamics: Study of energy changes
System: Part of universe under study
Surroundings: Everything outside system
Boundary: Separates system from surroundings
Open system: Exchanges both matter and energy
Closed system: Exchanges energy but not matter
Isolated system: Exchanges neither matter nor energy
State functions: Properties depending only on state (P, V, T, U, H, S, G)
Path functions: Properties depending on path (q, w)
Intensive properties: Independent of amount (T, P, density)
Extensive properties: Dependent on amount (mass, volume, U, H, S, G)
Internal energy (U): Total energy of system
Enthalpy (H): Heat content at constant pressure
Heat capacity: Heat required to raise temperature by 1°C
Specific heat: Heat capacity per gram
Molar heat capacity: Heat capacity per mole
C_p: Heat capacity at constant pressure
C_v: Heat capacity at constant volume
Isothermal process: Constant temperature
Adiabatic process: No heat exchange
Isobaric process: Constant pressure
Isochoric process: Constant volume
Cyclic process: Returns to initial state
Reversible process: Infinite small steps, equilibrium at every stage
Irreversible process: Finite steps, not in equilibrium
Spontaneous process: Occurs on its own without external help
Entropy (S): Measure of randomness/disorder
Gibbs free energy (G): Energy available to do useful work
Standard state: 1 bar pressure, 1 M concentration, pure substance
Standard enthalpy of formation: Enthalpy change when 1 mole formed from elements
Standard enthalpy of combustion: Enthalpy change when 1 mole completely burnt
Bond dissociation enthalpy: Energy to break one mole of bonds
Hess's law: Enthalpy change is path independent
Zeroth law: If A=B and B=C, then A=C (thermal equilibrium)
First law: Energy can't be created or destroyed
Second law: Entropy of universe always increases
Third law: Entropy of perfect crystal at 0 K is zero

formulas: Q_c = Reaction quotient (same form as K_c)
K for added reactions = K₁ × K₂
Le Chatelier's principle: System counteracts changes
K_a × K_b = K_w for conjugate pair
pH = 7 + ½pK_a + ½log C (Salt of weak acid & strong base)
pH = ½pK_a - ½pK_b (Salt of weak acid & weak base)
Buffer capacity = Number of moles of acid/base added / pH change
definitions: Equilibrium: State where forward and reverse rates are equal
Static equilibrium: No macroscopic change (rare in chemistry)
Dynamic equilibrium: Processes continue at molecular level
Homogeneous equilibrium: All reactants/products in same phase
Heterogeneous equilibrium: Different phases present
Law of mass action: Rate ∝ product of active masses
Equilibrium constant: Ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations at equilibrium
K_c: Equilibrium constant in terms of concentration
K_p: Equilibrium constant in terms of partial pressure
Reaction quotient (Q): Same form as K but at any time
Le Chatelier's principle: System at equilibrium responds to stress to minimize effect
Ionic equilibrium: Equilibrium involving ions
Acid: Substance that donates H⁺ (Arrhenius)/proton donor (Brønsted)
Base: Substance that donates OH⁻ (Arrhenius)/proton acceptor (Brønsted)
Conjugate acid-base pair: Differ by one H⁺
Lewis acid: Electron pair acceptor
Lewis base: Electron pair donor
Strong acid: Completely dissociates
Weak acid: Partially dissociates
Ka: Acid dissociation constant
Kb: Base dissociation constant
Kw: Ionic product of water
pH: Negative log of H⁺ concentration
pOH: Negative log of OH⁻ concentration
Buffer solution: Resists pH change
Acidic buffer: Weak acid + salt of weak acid
Basic buffer: Weak base + salt of weak base
Buffer capacity: Ability to resist pH change
Salt hydrolysis: Reaction of salt ions with water
Solubility product (Ksp): Product of ion concentrations at saturation
Common ion effect: Suppression of dissociation by common ion
Ostwald's dilution law: α = √(K_a/C) for weak electrolytes

formulas: Oxidation number = Charge atom would have if electrons transferred completely
Sum of oxidation numbers in neutral compound = 0
Sum of oxidation numbers in ion = Charge on ion
Oxidation: Increase in oxidation number, loss of electrons
Reduction: Decrease in oxidation number, gain of electrons
Oxidizing agent: Itself gets reduced, oxidizes others
Reducing agent: Itself gets oxidized, reduces others
n-factor for acids = Number of H⁺ ions donated
n-factor for bases = Number of OH⁻ ions donated
n-factor for oxidizing/reducing agents = Change in oxidation number
Number of equivalents = Mass / Equivalent weight
For balancing redox reactions (oxidation number method): Steps 1-6
For balancing redox reactions (half-reaction method): Steps 1-7
In acidic medium: Balance O with H₂O, H with H⁺
In basic medium: Balance O with H₂O, H with H⁺ then add OH⁻ to both sides
Oxidation state of oxygen: Usually -2 (except peroxides -1, superoxides -½, OF₂ +2)
Oxidation state of hydrogen: Usually +1 (except metal hydrides -1)
Oxidation state of alkaline earth metals: +2
Oxidation state of halogens: Usually -1 (except with oxygen)
Disproportionation: Same element oxidized and reduced
Comproportionation: Two different oxidation states form intermediate
definitions: Redox reaction: Reaction involving oxidation and reduction simultaneously
Oxidation: Loss of electrons, increase in oxidation number
Reduction: Gain of electrons, decrease in oxidation number
Oxidizing agent: Accepts electrons, gets reduced
Reducing agent: Donates electrons, gets oxidized
Oxidation number: Charge atom would have if electrons transferred completely
Oxidation state: Same as oxidation number
Disproportionation: Same element undergoes both oxidation and reduction
Comproportionation: Two different oxidation states form same intermediate state
Electrochemical cell: Device converting chemical energy to electrical
Electrode potential: Tendency to gain/lose electrons
Standard electrode potential: Measured under standard conditions (1 M, 1 bar, 298 K)
E°cell: Standard cell potential
Redox couple: Oxidized and reduced forms of same element
Salt bridge: Completes circuit, maintains electrical neutrality
Anode: Electrode where oxidation occurs
Cathode: Electrode where reduction occurs
Galvanic cell: Spontaneous redox reaction produces electricity
Electrolytic cell: Electricity drives non-spontaneous reaction
Equivalent weight: Mass that provides 1 mole of electrons
n-factor: Number of electrons gained/lost per molecule
Normality: Number of equivalents per liter
Titration: Quantitative analysis using reaction completion
Indicator: Substance that shows endpoint by color change
Auto-oxidation: Substance acts as both oxidizing and reducing agent

formulas: Degree of unsaturation (DU) = (2C + 2 - H + N - X)/2
DU = 1: One double bond or ring
DU = 2: Two double bonds, or one triple bond, or two rings, or one double + one ring
% C = (Mass of CO₂ × 12 × 100)/(44 × Mass of compound)
% H = (Mass of H₂O × 2 × 100)/(18 × Mass of compound)
% N by Dumas method = (Volume of N₂ at STP × 28 × 100)/(22400 × Mass of compound)
% N by Kjeldahl method = (1.4 × Normality of acid × Volume of acid)/Mass of compound
% X (halogen) = (Atomic mass of X × Mass of AgX × 100)/(Molecular mass of AgX × Mass of compound)
% S = (32 × Mass of BaSO₄ × 100)/(233 × Mass of compound)
% P = (31 × Mass of Mg₂P₂O₇ × 100)/(222 × Mass of compound)
Rf value = Distance moved by compound / Distance moved by solvent
Inductive effect: Permanent displacement of σ electrons
Electromeric effect: Temporary displacement of π electrons
Resonance energy = Experimental heat of formation - Calculated heat of formation
Stability order of free radicals: 3° > 2° > 1° > CH₃
Homolytic fission: Each atom gets one electron, forms free radicals
Heterolytic fission: One atom gets both electrons, forms ions
definitions: Organic chemistry: Study of carbon compounds
Catenation: Property of carbon to form bonds with itself
Tetravalency: Carbon forms 4 covalent bonds
Homologous series: Series with same functional group, differ by CH₂
Functional group: Atom or group responsible for characteristic reactions
Saturated compounds: Only single bonds
Unsaturated compounds: Double or triple bonds
Aliphatic compounds: Open chain or cyclic non-aromatic
Aromatic compounds: Benzene-like structure with delocalized electrons
IUPAC nomenclature: Systematic naming of organic compounds
Parent chain: Longest continuous carbon chain
Substituent: Group attached to parent chain
Locant: Number indicating position of substituent
Isomerism: Same molecular formula, different structures
Structural isomerism: Different bonding arrangement
Chain isomerism: Different carbon skeleton
Position isomerism: Different position of functional group
Functional isomerism: Different functional groups
Metamerism: Different alkyl groups on same functional group
Tautomerism: Dynamic equilibrium between isomers
Stereoisomerism: Same bonding, different spatial arrangement
Geometrical isomerism: Different arrangement around double bond
Optical isomerism: Non-superimposable mirror images
Electrophile: Electron-loving species (positive or neutral)
Nucleophile: Nucleus-loving species (negative or neutral)
Inductive effect: Polarization of σ bond
Electromeric effect: Complete transfer of π electrons
Resonance: Delocalization of π electrons
Hyperconjugation: σ-π conjugation (no bond resonance)
Homolytic fission: Symmetrical bond breaking
Heterolytic fission: Unsymmetrical bond breaking
Free radical: Species with unpaired electron
Carbocation: Carbon with positive charge
Carbanion: Carbon with negative charge
Carbene: :CH₂ with two unpaired electrons
Distillation: Separation based on boiling point
Crystallization: Purification based on solubility
Sublimation: Solid to vapor directly
Chromatography: Separation based on differential adsorption
Rf value: Retention factor in chromatography
Lassaigne's test: Test for elements in organic compounds

Organic Chemistry - Some Basic Principle.notes: Organic Chemistry Basics covers: Tetravalence of carbon, shapes of organic compounds, structural representations, classification of organic compounds, IUPAC nomenclature, isomerism (structural and stereoisomerism), fundamental concepts in organic reaction mechanism (fission of bonds, electrophiles, nucleophiles, free radicals, carbocations, carbanions), electron displacement effects (inductive, electromeric, resonance, hyperconjugation), methods of purification (distillation, crystallization, sublimation, chromatography), qualitative analysis (detection of C, H, N, S, halogens), quantitative analysis (estimation of elements).

formulas: Octane number = Measure of anti-knock properties
Cetane number = Measure of ignition quality of diesel
Markovnikov's rule: In addition of HX to alkene, H adds to C with more H
Anti-Markovnikov addition: With peroxide, H adds to less substituted C
Saytzeff's rule: More substituted alkene is major product in elimination
Bayer's test: Alkene decolorizes cold dilute KMnO₄
Ozonolysis: C=C + O₃ → ozonide → carbonyl compounds
Friedel-Crafts alkylation: Benzene + R-X + AlCl₃ → R-Benzene
Friedel-Crafts acylation: Benzene + R-CO-Cl + AlCl₃ → R-CO-Benzene
Nitration: C₆H₆ + HNO₃ + H₂SO₄ → C₆H₅NO₂ + H₂O
Halogenation: C₆H₆ + X₂ + FeX₃ → C₆H₅X + HX
Hydroboration: Alkene + BH₃ → Alkyl borane → Alcohol
Acidic hydrogen: Terminal alkynes have acidic H (pKa ≈ 25)
definitions: Hydrocarbon: Compound containing only C and H
Alkanes: Saturated hydrocarbons with single bonds
Alkenes: Unsaturated with at least one C=C
Alkynes: Unsaturated with at least one C≡C
Arenes: Aromatic hydrocarbons
Saturated: All bonds are single
Unsaturated: Contains double or triple bonds
Conformations: Different spatial arrangements from bond rotation
Staggered conformation: Most stable, bonds as far apart as possible
Eclipsed conformation: Least stable, bonds as close as possible
Geometrical isomerism: cis-trans due to restricted rotation
cis-isomer: Same groups on same side
trans-isomer: Same groups on opposite sides
Markovnikov's rule: H adds to C with more H in addition to unsymmetrical alkene
Anti-Markovnikov addition: Opposite of Markovnikov (with peroxide)
Saytzeff's rule: More substituted alkene is major product in elimination
Ozonolysis: Cleavage of alkene with ozone to give carbonyls
Polymerization: Joining of monomers to form polymer
Aromaticity: Special stability from cyclic delocalization
Hückel's rule: Aromatic if planar, cyclic, (4n+2)π electrons
Electrophilic substitution: Characteristic reaction of arenes
Friedel-Crafts reaction: Introduction of alkyl or acyl group
Directive effect: Substituent directs incoming group to ortho, para or meta
Ortho-para directors: Activating groups (except halogens)
Meta directors: Deactivating groups
Carcinogenicity: Cancer-causing property of some hydrocarbons

Hydrocarbons.notes: Hydrocarbons covers: Classification, alkanes (nomenclature, isomerism, conformations, preparation, properties, reactions - halogenation, combustion, pyrolysis), alkenes (nomenclature, structure of double bond, geometrical isomerism, preparation, properties, reactions - addition of HX (Markovnikov/anti-Markovnikov), addition of water, halogen, hydrogen, ozonolysis, oxidation, polymerization), alkynes (nomenclature, structure of triple bond, preparation, properties, acidic nature, addition reactions), aromatic hydrocarbons (benzene structure, resonance, aromaticity, Hückel's rule, electrophilic substitution reactions - nitration, sulfonation, halogenation, Friedel-Crafts reactions, directive effects).
